newsitem.title: USA: RESEARCH ALERT - Needham reiterates Citrix.
newsitem.headline: RESEARCH ALERT - Needham reiterates Citrix.

text.p: -- Needham & Co analyst Mike Cristinziano said he reiterrated his strong buy rating on Citrix Systems Inc and described a sell-off that occurred Thursday as "irrational."

-- The analyst said the company was the victim of a variety of market rumors, resurfaced old news and a negative write-up in a technical analysis newsletter. "Most of it was rumor or unwarranted concern," he said.

-- Citrix makes remote access software that allows a variety of computer systems and electronic appliances to run Microsoft Corp Windows applications without having the entire Windows operating system present on their machines.
-- Thursday, the stock had given back more than 10 points to fall to 29-1/8, amidst a generally weak day for tech stocks, but rebounded some in early trading Friday morning, gaining 3-3/8 to 32-1/2.
-- Specifically, he said that concerns about the company's close relationship to Microsoft and Microsoft's future product plans were unwarranted.
-- "The most significant rumor that is absolutely unture is that Microsoft cancelled its agreement to license Windows NT to Citrix," Cristinziano said.

-- Compounding this were resurfaced concerns that Intel Corp and Microsoft's "zero administration PC" effort, introduced in fourth quarter 1996, would kill Citrix's plans to sell Windows-based software for network computers.

-- The analyst allowed that he has not been able to verify a rumor that Microsoft may be planning to integrate multi-user access features into the next major release of Window NT (5.0) that would eliminate the need for a key Citrix technology.

-- However, he dismissed the idea Microsoft would make introduction of multi-user access a priority within the next two years, given that Citrix already offers the features and that Microsoft benefits from Citrix's success, since Microsoft holds a six percent stake in Citrix.

-- "This is a company that is going to grow over 100 percent over the next two years," he said, adding that at 35 times his 1997 estimate of $87.5 million in revenues and $0.83 in earnings per share, "the stock is damn cheap."
